103.text:
in because the west coast
salmon have this habit of --

108.text:
Nearly all of them die -- All

They come back and they die
and they don't go quietly.

122.text: They can die in very large numbers.

124.text: They can wash up on shores of larger streams.

127.text: They get hung up on logs.

128.text: They can stay in the stream.

129.text:
A lot of them get flushed
out into the estuaries.

132.text:
And as a result of predation by bears and
wolves, of course, many of them can end up right

138.text:
up in the forest, where they can leave a
very large part of their carcasses behind.

142.text:
So, when I see something like this,
I sort of envision a conveyor belt

146.text:
of marine derived nutrients which
are coming up the streams every fall

150.text: and this goes on over a very large area.

And so the area I'm interested in
applying this to is our understanding

158.text:
of how cross-boundary nutrient subsidies
work, and there are other examples.

162.text:
So, for example, on islands well known examples
are seaweed washing up, as you can see here,

167.text:
or bird colonies, where you
have lots of guano deposited.

171.text:
These are marine derived nutrients, and then
those can end up on land, where they can end

177.text:
up supporting some very interesting terrestrial
food webs, which a very large proportion

184.text:
of the productivity is driven by
nutrients coming from the sea.

188.text: And, of course, they can go the other way.

189.text:
So, freshwater people are quite
used to the idea that, for example,

195.text:
terrestrial insects fall off branches; they
land in the streams, where they're gobbled

199.text:
up by resident fish, for example; and, of
course, they can bounce back out in another way

205.text:
through aquatic insects going
into their terrestrial phase

208.text: and then winding up in terrestrial food webs.

210.text:
So, there's this trafficking
of energy and material

216.text:
between these three so-called ecosystems,
which can make it a lot more interesting

223.text:
to understand what's going on with it
in each of them, and that's the topic

227.text: that I'm going to be looking at today.

236.text:
They go all the way from California

He's got a whole truckload

because they think this is a good thing to

290.text:

297.text:
and Oceans wrote on salmon carcass-planting

But there is already this idea that

311.text:
and sustaining our freshwater

We'll talk about aquatic
stream insects, coho salmon.

There is a marine access here, too,

But what I'm going to do is I'm just

of the work we'll be doing, asking this

of salmon on various elements

So, I want to begin then

So, we've had a couple of people working on

ratio and here it is plotted against

So, each of these is a different
stream, although we may have more

914.text: than one trophic group of insect on the way.

especially the upper levels,

and that's particularly true in the fall; and

but we can still kind of see
a bit of a legacy of this

They seem to be consuming

Some of it may be coming directly

This has been foreshadowed by some

and I think that this is the scouring

I think that when the salmon arrive,

1003.text:
in the spawning region --
which the salmon are there --

and I think it's because

So, this is an example of the engineering

up the nutrients, I think the engineering

Clearly those numbers are rebounding

But it does appear that they're

straight to sea -- whether their nutrients

or pink salmon by itself,
